items.title: Bank Lending in Euro Zone Slumped in November, Data Show
items.author: By Jack Ewing
items.abstract: The European Central Bank said lending to companies remained weak, while loans to households registered feeble growth.

items.title: I.B.M. Slims Down Its Big Data Offerings
items.author: By Steve Lohr
items.abstract: In an effort to compete more aggressively with the makers of industry-standard computers, I.B.M. is cutting the price on its least-expensive Power server computers by 50 percent to appeal to small- and medium-size businesses.

items.title: That Tesla Data: What It Says and What It Doesn’t
items.author: By John M. Broder
items.abstract: About three hours into the trip, the reporter placed the first of about a dozen calls to Tesla personnel expressing concern about the car’s declining range.

items.title: Data, Stimulus, and Human Nature
items.author: By Paul Krugman
items.abstract: Don’t blame the numbers.

items.title: Renewed Signs of Europe’s Economic Weakness
items.author: By James Kanter
items.abstract: As a leading European official warned that the euro-area economy would shrink for a second year, Moody’s downgraded Britain’s government bonds from its top rating.

items.title: Trying to Wean Britons From Unlimited Mobile Data
items.author: By Kevin J. O'Brien
items.abstract: By tying the volume of Web surfing to the price on its new 4G service, the mobile operator EE hopes to end limitless data packages for smartphone users.

items.title: Affirmative Action: Looking at the Data
items.abstract: Readers react to a Sunday Review essay about recent studies questioning how successful the program is.

items.title: Designing Big Data That Works
items.author: By Quentin Hardy
items.abstract: Cloud computing and mobility have brought to the fore an unexpected strategic asset from the humanities: design. A start-up called Tidemark, which sells cloud-based business analytics software, has introduced a series of planning features designed to speed forecasting and decision making.

items.title: Air Pollution Linked to 1.2 Million Premature Deaths in China
items.author: By Edward Wong
items.abstract: Air pollution was the fourth leading risk factor for deaths in China, accounting for the loss of 25 million healthy years of life from the population, a study said.

items.title: The G.O.P.’s Digital Makeover
items.author: By Thomas B. Edsall
items.abstract: Republican strategists wonder whether they can catch up to Obama’s Democrats on data mining, microtargeting and other contemporary campaign techniques.

items.title: With Better Security Technology, Hotels Shore Up Blind Spots
items.author: By Julie Weed
items.abstract: Hotels are beefing up security with new key cards, smaller cameras and employee training.

items.title: Payroll Data Shows a Lag in Wages, Not Just Hiring
items.author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
items.abstract: Payrolls in the United States grew by 113,000 in January, a weaker-than-expected increase that experts said may signal a loss of momentum in the economy. The unemployment rate dipped to 6.6 percent.

items.title: Water-Cleaning Technology Could Help Farmers
items.author: By Todd Woody
items.abstract: A project developed by WaterFX, a start-up in drought-stricken California, exploits two things the Central Valley possesses in abundance — fallow land and sunshine — to cut desalinization costs.

items.title: A Content Company Weighs Becoming a Technology Company
items.author: By Bryan Borzykowski
items.abstract: A start-up looks for a way to get stalled revenue growth moving again.

items.title: Disney Throws Open the Gates to Its Own Digital Movie Service
items.author: By Brooks Barnes
items.abstract: The Disney Movies Anywhere online service will link to consumers’ iTunes accounts and is intended to encourage digital movie sales, rather than rentals.

items.title: Data Breach Hurts Profit at Target
items.author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
items.abstract: The retailer reported that profit plunged 46 percent in the fourth quarter of 2013 and attributed it to revelations of customer data theft.

items.title: The Sweet, Streaming Sound of Data
items.author: By Ben Sisario
items.abstract: With the music industry turning digital, music companies can now understand their customers’ listening habits in greater depth than ever before.

items.title: Wind Industry’s New Technologies Are Helping It Compete on Price
items.author: By Diane Cardwell
items.abstract: With new technology, the industry has been able to produce more power at lower cost by capturing the faster winds that blow at higher elevations.

items.title: Technology’s Man Problem
items.author: By Claire Cain Miller
items.abstract: Crude apps, patronizing behavior. For some, “bro” culture offers one explanation for why there are so few women in tech.

items.title: China G.D.P. Growth at Slowest Pace Since 2009, Data Shows
items.author: By Neil Gough
items.abstract: The economy grew at a 6.8 percent pace in the fourth quarter, official data released Tuesday showed — the slowest expansion since March 2009.

items.title: U.S. Economy Barely Grew Last Quarter, Stoking Concerns About Momentum in 2016
items.author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
items.abstract: The economy is facing headwinds like turmoil in global markets, but the job and housing markets remain strong.

items.title: Microsoft Plumbs Ocean’s Depths to Test Underwater Data Center
items.author: By John Markoff
items.abstract: Microsoft sank a data center on the ocean floor, where the sea water acts as a coolant, and plans to use the waves to power it. The results were encouraging enough to try a bigger version.

items.title: Report Cites Dangers of Autonomous Weapons
items.author: By John Markoff
items.abstract: A former Pentagon official who helped establish United States policy on such weapons says they could be uncontrollable in real-world situations.
keywords: Center for a New American Security

items.title: At RSA Conference, Unlikely Allies Address Value of Digital Security
items.author: By Nicole Perlroth
items.abstract: Given Apple’s dispute with the F.B.I., what surprised many at the world’s largest gathering of security experts was the nuanced tone of former government officials.
keywords: RSA, The Security Division of EMC Corporation

items.title: Making Technology Easier for Older People to Use
items.author: By Constance Gustke
items.abstract: The predigital generation is receiving help navigating the wired world from senior centers, advocacy groups and specially designed devices.

items.title: In the Apple Case, a Debate Over Data Hits Home
items.author: By Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Katie Benner
items.abstract: The debate that began three years ago after revelations about government surveillance has become more personal, now that smartphones are involved.

items.title: VW Whistle-Blower’s Suit Accuses Carmaker of Deleting Data
items.author: By Jack Ewing
items.abstract: A fired Volkswagen employee in Michigan contends that employees erased electronic files as U.S. officials were investigating its emissions cheating.

items.title: Watch Brands Looking for New in Era of 'Smart'
items.author: By Victoria Gomelsky
items.abstract: Even as sales wane, optimists believe that growth is within reach for fine Swiss watchmakers.

items.title: Senator Wants Data on Wounded Warrior Project, a Charity Under Fire
items.author: By Dave Philipps
items.abstract: Recent news reports have raised questions about the treatment of employees and the spending of the country’s largest veterans’ charity.

items.title: A Holistic Facialist’s Guide to Total Wellness
items.author: By Alainna Lexie Beddie
items.abstract: If Tess Adams of Take Care spa can’t fix what ails you with facials or massage or microcurrent technology, she knows just where in New York to send you.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg, in Suit, Testifies in Oculus Intellectual Property Trial
items.author: By Nick Wingfield and Mike Isaac
items.abstract: Oculus, a virtual reality company acquired by Facebook, is accused of stealing elements of the technology that went into its headsets.

items.title: Tasmanian Tigers’ Brains Yield Clues Long After Extinction
items.author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
items.abstract: The last thylacine died in a zoo in 1936, but neural scans of preserved specimens revealed that they may have been more intelligent than previously believed.

items.title: The Internet of Things Is Coming for Us
items.author: By William Neuman and Luis Jaime Castillo Butters
items.abstract: Ancient Moche artists anticipated our most modern fears.

items.title: Smart Approaches, Not Strong-Arm Tactics, to Jobs
items.author: By Thomas L. Friedman
items.abstract: Democrats need to take the long view.

items.title: China’s Intelligent Weaponry Gets Smarter
items.author: By John Markoff and Matthew Rosenberg
items.abstract: The United States no longer has a strategic monopoly on a technology that is widely seen as the key factor in the next generation of warfare.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Activists Rush to Save Government Science Data — If They Can Find It
items.author: By Amy Harmon
items.abstract: The Trump administration has begun changing some government websites. A group of concerned citizens has been working to preserve data it sees as politically vulnerable.

items.title: Mets’ Bruce Digs Into Data to Find the Right Swing
items.author: By James Wagner
items.abstract: A bad August at the plate after being traded to the Mets last year led Jay Bruce to research what went wrong. He found it in the game’s new numbers.

items.title: How to Use Technology to Outsource Pet Care
items.author: By Brian X. Chen
items.abstract: A growing number of start-ups offer apps and gadgets to help you walk your dog or feed your cat, but most aren’t worth the money.

items.title: Trump Leaves Science Jobs Vacant, Troubling Critics
items.author: By Cecilia Kang and Michael D. Shear
items.abstract: Scores of scientists and technology experts have left the White House, and conservatives — and the president — have questioned whether they need to be replaced.

items.title: Data on Europe’s Economy, Job Numbers and Janet Yellen’s Goodbye
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: The Fed meeting this week, Janet Yellen’s last as chairwoman will probably pass quietly, while earnings season for tech companies begins with a bang.

items.title: School Shooting Simulation Trains Teachers for the Worst
items.author: By Jason M. Bailey
items.abstract: New software funded by the Department of Homeland Security features a virtual school stalked by an active shooter.

items.title: When You’re a ‘Digital Nomad,’ the World Is Your Office
items.author: By Kyle Chayka
items.abstract: A global network of live-work spaces is springing up to serve this new breed of millennial wanderer.

items.title: How Artificial Intelligence Is Edging Its Way Into Our Lives
items.author: By The New York Times
items.abstract: Artificial intelligence is here, and its effects are being felt across how we work. The New York Times examines the impact at its New Work Summit on Feb. 12 and 13.

items.title: The Struggle to Build a Massive ‘Biobank’ of Patient Data
items.author: By Gina Kolata
items.abstract: At a cost of $1.4 billion, a National Institutes of Health program may help scientists discover links between diseases, genes and lifestyle. But the project faces obstacles.

items.title: U.S. Officials Warn Health Researchers: China May Be Trying to Steal Your Data
items.author: By Robert Pear
items.abstract: The Trump administration expressed concern about foreign threats to biomedical research funded by the National Institutes of Health and said the risks were growing.

items.title: Here’s How the Shutdown Is Delaying Climate Data and Undercutting Scientists
items.author: By Kendra Pierre-Louis
items.abstract: A key global temperature report isn’t coming out this week because of missing data, and some long-term research projects are at risk.

items.title: Data Breaches Dent Singapore’s Image as a Tech Innovator
items.author: By Mike Ives
items.abstract: Experts say security concerns are a pitfall for countries that are pushing to make vast troves of data more accessible and centralized.

items.title: Digital Media: What Went Wrong
items.author: By Edmund Lee
items.abstract: For years, BuzzFeed seemed to be leading the journalism industry toward a brave new future. Now that it has stumbled, the way ahead looks more old-school than ever.

items.title: A High-Tech Pill to End Drug Injections
items.author: By Gina Kolata
items.abstract: Engineers have developed a tiny robotic capsule that injects insulin once it lands in the stomach.

items.title: Is Blockchain Technology Overhyped?
items.author: By James Ryerson
items.abstract: Two books by legal scholars argue that the revolutionary promise of the new database tool has been exaggerated.
keywords: Blockchain and the Law: The Rule of Code (Book)
The Blockchain and the New Architecture of Trust (Book)

items.title: Ford Is Investigating Emissions and Fuel Efficiency Data
items.author: By Natasha Singer
items.abstract: The company has hired a law firm to look into how it tested vehicles after employees reported possible flaws with its computer models.

items.title: After Hitting Rock Bottom, the Orioles Turn to Data, and a New G.M.
items.author: By Tyler Kepner
items.abstract: After a 47-115 disaster last season, the Orioles hired Mike Elias from the Astros for a complete rebuild. First step: embracing analytics.

items.title: How to Become a ‘Digital Nomad’
items.author: By Kristin Wong
items.abstract: Seeing the world while holding down a full-time job sounds too good to be true, but with the right planning, equipment and support, it can be done.

items.title: My Company’s I.T. Director Is Holding My Data Hostage
items.author: By Katy Lederer
items.abstract: It really is time we all learned how to code.

items.title: A Tech Insider Stylishly Chronicles Her Industry’s ‘Uncanny Valley’
items.author: By Lauren Oyler
items.abstract: Anna Wiener’s memoir captures the dreams, delusions and general absurdity of Silicon Valley in indelible detail.

items.title: He Overcame Setbacks to Thrive in Information Technology
items.author: By John L. Dorman
items.abstract: Five years ago, Darius Jones had trouble coming up with subway fare. Today, he is an I.T. analyst for one of the world’s most exclusive luxury brands.
keywords: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
Community Service Society of New York

items.title: 2019 Was a Record Year for Ocean Temperatures, Data Show
items.author: By Kendra Pierre-Louis
items.abstract: A new analysis found 2019 was the hottest for the world’s oceans. The five hottest years have also been in the past five years.

items.title: Elizabeth Warren’s Smart Answer on ‘Electability’
items.author: By Melanye Price
items.abstract: She was right to push the conversation on gender and the presidency.

items.title: Review: Competing in the Digital Age
items.author: By Jonathan A. Knee
items.abstract: Two new books examine how digital technologies are transforming businesses and the economy, and look at the resulting ethical and regulatory concerns.
keywords: Competing in the Age of AI: Strategy and Leadership When Algorithms and Networks Run the World (Book)
The Business of Platforms: Strategy in the Age of Digital Competition, Innovation, and Power (Book)

items.title: One Thing You Can Do: Make Smart Donations
items.author: By Susan Shain, Shola Lawal and Brad Plumer
items.abstract: Also this week, African climate activists and a popular Berkeley class

items.title: A Comic Coming-of-Age Novel Laced With Social Commentary
items.author: By Tommy Orange
items.abstract: Gabriel Bump’s “Everywhere You Don’t Belong,” about a young black man from Chicago’s South Side, balances emotional heaviness and levity, Tommy Orange writes in his review.

items.title: Tesla Faces a New S.E.C. Investigation
items.author: By Niraj Chokshi
items.abstract: The electric-car maker said the agency was also looking into contracts and “regular financing arrangements.”

items.title: How Technology Is Changing the Future of Higher Education
items.author: By Jon Marcus
items.abstract: Labs test artificial intelligence, virtual reality and other innovations that could improve learning and lower costs for Generation Z and beyond.

items.title: A Hong Kong Website Gets Blocked, Raising Censorship Fears
items.author: By Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik
items.abstract: Users of major mobile carriers can no longer access a service that detailed the personal information of police officers, a possible sign that the city is turning to tactics used in mainland China.

items.title: Slouch or Slack Off, This ‘Smart’ Office Chair Cushion Will Record It
items.author: By Tiffany May and Amy Chang Chien
items.abstract: A Chinese tech company designed a way to track employees’ health, but sensors were also monitoring when they were away from their desks, setting off a debate about privacy and surveillance.

items.title: Keys to an Equitable Recovery: Better Data and ‘Trusted Messengers’
items.author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
items.abstract: Vast racial health disparities are not accidental and can be fixed, says Dr. Marcella Nunez-Smith, head of Biden’s Covid-19 Health Equity Task Force.
keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

items.title: James R. Flynn, Who Found We Are Getting Smarter, Dies at 86
items.author: By Clay Risen
items.abstract: A philosopher who moved into psychology and studied I.Q., he showed that as society grows more technical, human intellectual abilities expand to meet the challenge.

items.title: The Soothing, Digital Rooms of YouTube
items.author: By Eliza Brooke
items.abstract: Ambience videos pair relaxing soundscapes with animated scenery to make viewers feel immersed in specific spaces, like a cozy library. They’re big with “Harry Potter” fans.

items.title: The Smart Way to Grow Roses
items.author: By Margaret Roach
items.abstract: It’s the season for ordering roses. Here’s how to choose the right ones — and how to grow them sustainably once you’ve got them.

items.title: A Smarter App Is Watching Your Wallet
items.author: By Alina Tugend
items.abstract: As artificial intelligence evolves, personal finance programs are working to offer you, and your budget, tailored advice.

items.title: Pennsylvania Woman Accused of Using Deepfake Technology to Harass Cheerleaders
items.author: By Christina Morales
items.abstract: Three teenagers in a Bucks County cheerleading program were subjected to a campaign of harassment using altered videos and spoof phone numbers, police officials said.

items.title: Why Starting a Restaurant During the Pandemic Was a Smart Move
items.author: By Pete Wells
items.abstract: Those that did may be better off, their owners say, because they could meet the moment’s restrictions and cravings from the very start.

items.title: Mixed Virus Data Has Some Experts Questioning Pace of N.Y.C. Reopening
items.author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced this week that businesses like indoor fitness studios would be allowed to reopen.

items.title: Lisa Goddard, 55, Dies; Brought Climate Data to Those Who Needed It
items.author: By Clay Risen
items.abstract: She helped show government agencies around the world how to predict upcoming droughts, flooding and other extreme weather events.
keywords: International Research Institute for Climate and Society (Columbia University)

items.title: Prepare Yourself for This Weekend’s ‘Crypto Bowl’
items.author: By Tiffany Hsu
items.abstract: The Super Bowl will feature commercial breaks that embrace the usual jokes and celebrities plus a whole lot of blockchain.

items.title: The U.S. extends technology restrictions to Belarus and the Russian oil industry.
items.author: By Ana Swanson
items.abstract: The Biden administration said the measures would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia.
keywords: United States Defense and Military Forces

items.title: Carmakers Race to Control Next-Generation Battery Technology
items.author: By Jack Ewing and Eric Lipton
items.abstract: The prize: batteries that would be cheaper, faster to charge and less vulnerable to raw material shortages. Whoever gets there first will have a major advantage.

items.title: Weight Watchers App Gathered Data From Children, F.T.C. Says
items.author: By Claire Fahy
items.abstract: Kurbo by WW, a weight-loss app geared toward children, illegally collected data from users as young as 8 without their parents’ consent, the Federal Trade Commission said in a complaint.

items.title: A New City, Built Upon Data, Takes Shape in South Korea
items.author: By David Belcher
items.abstract: Fifty-four families volunteered to share data on everything from sleeping habits to trash volume to help developers make a city from scratch in Busan.

items.title: Forecasters Face Loss of Data as Weather Balloon Flights Are Cut
items.author: By Henry Fountain
items.abstract: Disruptions to supplies of hydrogen and helium have led the National Weather Service to cancel routine launches at some sites.

items.title: White House Aims to Reflect the Environment in Economic Data
items.author: By Lydia DePillis
items.abstract: The Biden administration has set out to measure the economic value of ecosystems, offering new statistics to weigh in policy decisions.

items.title: Ford Will Build a U.S. Battery Factory With Technology From China
items.author: By Neal E. Boudette and Keith Bradsher
items.abstract: Ford’s $3.5 billion plant in Michigan will draw on technology from CATL, a Chinese company that is the world’s No. 1 maker of electric-car batteries.

items.title: Vice C.E.O.’s Departure Signals Fallen Hopes for Digital Media
items.author: By Benjamin Mullin
items.abstract: Nancy Dubuc is leaving the media company, which is exploring a sale of some or all of the business, after nearly five years there.

items.title: New Data Links Pandemic’s Origins to Raccoon Dogs at Wuhan Market
items.author: By Benjamin Mueller
items.abstract: Genetic samples from the market were recently uploaded to an international database and then removed after scientists asked China about them.

items.title: Scare Me Once? Great Game. Scare Me Twice? Great Remake.
items.author: By Zachary Small
items.abstract: New versions of Resident Evil 4 and Dead Space illustrate the challenges that video game developers face when immersing players in horrifying yet familiar worlds.

items.title: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
items.author: By Gabriel J.X. Dance, Tim Wallace and Zach Levitt
items.abstract: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.

items.title: Unemployment Is Low. Inflation Is Falling. But What Comes Next?
items.author: By Ben Casselman
items.abstract: Despite hopeful signs, economists worry that a recession is on the way or that the Federal Reserve will cause one in trying to rein in inflation.

items.title: New Rules for Power Plants Could Give Carbon Capture a Boost. Here’s How.
items.author: By Brad Plumer
items.abstract: The technology has struggled to gain traction, but strict new emissions limits for gas and coal stations could encourage broader adoption.

items.title: U.S. Wires Ukraine With Radiation Sensors to Detect Nuclear Blasts
items.author: By William J. Broad
items.abstract: The federal National Nuclear Security Administration is setting up an advanced network that can verify an attacker’s identity.
